comments.commentBody:
I would not be that familiar with Putin to just call him Vlad, first name terms almost. Let us just call him Vladimir Trump.
The spoiled child will always come up with some new thing; oh he did it to me and I know it. "He took my toys and I am so upset now". "He tapped my phone when I was talking to Vladimir"
This is so funny, not
When our president thinks Breitbart is real news and the New York Times  is fake we have a real problem.
and all other people. . .

Trump is finally getting the clue about the caliber of evidence illuminating his and his minions misdeeds in talking with Russia. As with Nixon it took time for Nixon's misdeeds to bubble out into the open. For now, something clearly is rotting inside the oval office.

President Pence anyone?
The Church Lady was hand-picked by Donald and hasn't shown any remorse or alarm over what's happening.   Not much of a recommendation for the presidency.

Your logic is so flawed it's breathtaking.  Donald Trump repeatedly stated that Obama was not born in the U.S.  Is that true because Obama could have sued prove that what Trump said false, but didn't?

Honestly, why is the media even bothering with this?  Clearly Trump is attempting to deflect the news cycle away from Russian interference in the election, so if the NYTimes, et al., just ignored the tweet and stay the course Americans, and the world, would be better off.  Bannon and Trump have figured out how to control the news cycle -- its up to the media to change take back what constitutes importance.  If your editors think these Obama tapping tweets are newsworthy, then by all means report on it...,  on page twelve in the bottom left corner just above the ad for the mattresses.

Yes - you're right, Mr Trump - your phones are tapped!!
In fact, your wires are tapped, too.
If you look at the picture under the headline for this story, why are all those strips of paper on YOUR side of the aisle??
Just a few strips of paper where President Obama is sitting...
Coincidence? I think not !!!
Are those really JUST strips of paper??
Something is up there !!
Is he 'presidential' now Fourth Estate? give this as much coverage as you did to his State of the Union performance.

J, I think you swung and missed on this one. Obama should sue for defamation of character. I dont get your indictment take and anyway, Presidents dont indict, that job belongs to the Justice Department and Attorney General.
Trump doesn't need evidence or proof to convince his supporters. They'd believe him if he said the moon was made of green cheese.
And don't forget that there were an additional 8 million votes for third party candidates. Total 11 million votes against Trump.
He's done it. He has rendered me mute.
President Trump just started acting like the paranoid self-destructive leader #2 in "Hammer into Anvil"  in fictional sci-fi TV show, "The Prisoner" -- time to report yourself in...

As president of the United States (and really all us of) shouldn't we be held accountable for making incendiary statements without evidence? Is there a law against this? I'm pretty sure there isn't, but this president has changed the rules and when he claims he has incriminating information without proof, he should be reprimanded for making statements without doing his homework. If his "factual information" comes from a source, the source should be sued for promoting lies. Perhaps if there were a consequence for making statements without proof, POTUS would be more thoughtful before Tweeting his mind.
Sorry can't do, his majesty the Donald comes first.

This president is so unbalanced that should he loose the next election there will be no peaceful transfer of power. And with each passing day he, and his Republican minions in Congress, looks smaller and smaller. The emperor has no clothes, yet Congressional Republicans lavish effusive praise on his fine raiments.
There is a very good reason why Trump's line in his speech Tuesday about moving beyond "small talk and petty attacks" elicited audible giggles in the congressional chambers.

Trump's day so far:
6:35–7:02 a.m.: Claims he's uncovered a Watergate-level conspiracy
8:19 a.m.: Tweets about reality TV
9:26 a.m.: Golf
12:00 p.m.: Huge container of Kentucky Fried Chicken for lunch
I think he was overloaded on "Fox and Friends"  and Lucky Charms at 6:30 AM. Its a distraction to keep the public off of Russia and how he will handle North Korea.

Given that there was emerging evidence that Russian sources were seeking to influence the U.S. electoral process in a covert and highly illegal manner, and that there seemed to be an inexplicable amount of contact between the Trump campaign and various Russian officials, it would scarcely be surprising if U.S. intelligence agencies had sought an order to monitor communications between Trump campaign members and Russian sources.

Of more interest is whether Mike Flynn may have been deliberately entrapped by the Russians. The key phone call seems to have been initiated by the Russian ambassador while Flynn was on holiday in the Dominican Republic. Flynn would have been fully aware that Kislyak's calls were routinely monitored. As would (and this is the key point) Kislyak himself. Flynn may have assumed Kislyak was calling from a secured line. Or he may simply have been caught unawares and drawn deeper into the conversation around sanctions than he intended. But it seems highly likely that the late Mr Kislyak himself would know that the line was not secure. For all we know, the Russians may have had a hand themselves in subsequent leaks.

If the document "The Foundations of Geopolitics: The Geopolitical Future of Russia" is genuine this is exactly the sort of thing the Russians had been planning.
The Russian ambassador to the U.N., and the Russian ambassador to Turkey have Ied recently, but not (as of this minute as far as I know) Ambassador to the USA from Russia, Mr. Kislyak.

"AmeriCorps is on a draft White House budget office list of programs the president might eliminate to get to “small government.” And Trump has not yet appointed anyone to head the Corporation for National and Community Service."

Mr. Trump is penny wise and pound foolish. I maintain he's not interested in solving real problems so much as inventing problems that he convinces others only he can fix.

If he were truly interested in uniting the country, he'd read this column of yours Mr. Cohen. But the man thrives on division so he can boost his ego by pretending to be the great white hope of a fearful crowd.

It's a small, rotten way to live. Out at dinner with my boyfriend, I could only remark that Trump is not only an unhappy man at his core, he's a really mean-spirited one too. Unless he's the sole focus of attention, he's not interested in any program.

And since the very nature of community service involves cooperation of the many to help the many, there's simply no room for an egomaniac like Trump. Unless something is his idea, unless he's being adulated, he gets no enjoyment.

Again, I love your suggestions Mr. Cohen, and God knows we could use some common ground in this country. But even if we found it, I suspect that as long as selfish Donald is in charge, he'd do his best to drive us apart again.

Lovely sentiments, but what's actually being suggested? Sending 18-year-olds with no skills to spend a year away from home in poor towns. Those youths have absolutely nothing to offer to help those poor towns, and won't learn it in a year. The locals will hate them. The 18-year-olds will come back to their suburbs vowing never to go more than 50 miles from an ocean again.

Why do East coast liberals always believe "It's the thought that counts"? It isn't. Do something sensible that works. Don't just make gestures of compassion.

@ While deploring Trump's divisiveness, liberal elitists,living in posh college towns where populace is 90 percent white,and homes go for  half million and up, are sowing divisiveness themselves.We say in French, to "semer la zizanie!"I don't think a man who is worth billions and has accomplished the once thought impossible and gotten himself elected President of the US is all that unhappy. Is there an element of jealousy here? Americacorps is an excellent idea but don't we already have Vista?Agree with commenter who wrote that Peacecorps helped its volunteers more than it did the indigenous folk who were the beneficiaries of their volunteerism. In many cases that was true, in others no.While a TFA volunteer in Boke, Guinea, Juliana and I lived in a villa overlooking Rio Nunez, and just down the road from the Peacecorps h.q. where volunteers would come in from the bush for r & r. They were very nice to us, and recall fondly Thanksgiving dinner we were invited to roughly a decade ago. By contrast with US Embassy folk, they spoke the indigenous languages, and were highly thought of by the villageois.But Mr. Cohen has really found his voice in this article, and merits a "triple ban!"

@Tom: But you don't know, do you whether such an endeavor would be beneficial to both parties.In some cases yes, in other cases perhaps not.It can;t do any harm, and would broaden the horizons of everyone concerned. To see how the other half lives is always good."Term "east coast liberal"has come to have a pejorative connotation, but is also unfair.I live on the east coast, am liberal in advocating more financial assistance for the truly down and out, and how can that be a bad thing?"To say "the locals will hate them"insane, makes no sense at all.Recall op ed by an Englisman published in the Times over a year ago who moved into a ramshackle house in Pluto, Mississippi. He was there to help the locals through an ngo. He was welcomed with open arms by the locals who went out of their way to help him furnish his modest digs. Don't underestimate the generosity of the American people.Remember the glass is always half full.

Trump, offering no proof; falsely said...

More then can even be listed here. As I began to list the proven falsehoods, I had already exceeded the 1500 characters allowed by this comment section...and was barely getting warmed up.

At this point there is no longer any legitimate question about whether or not Trump is a liar. Whether it's compulsive, pathological or strategic the distinction seems only academic now.

I would argue that one of the most important questions we face now is exactly where is the line in the sand that republican leadership is unwilling to cross over to? Is there one?

Ok.  The Founding Fathers thought through what to if a President becomes unstable, unable to serve.  The people need to start demanding this be enacted.  But if the whole campaign was involved in trying to manipulate an election with another country, it doesn't seem like we should keep any of them in.  That part doesn't seem to have a constitutional solution.
The comparison with "Nixon/Watergate" is hardly apt.  But his turn is coming.

President Obama was born in Hawaii. Yet for years, private citizen Donald Trump made outrageous false claims that Obama was secretly born in Kenya, and unsubstantiated claims that he, Trump, sent investigators to Hawaii on the trail of this claim. He said, "I have people that have been studying it and they cannot believe what they're finding." Clearly, he knew how to phrase it so as to avoid a more detailed slander. To date, there is no evidence that he actually hired investigators.

So today the press is jumping on a new shiny object; new unsubstantiated claims about Obama from the same person who repeatedly told a rather transparent falsehood about Obama years ago. Despite the sad reality that Trump is now President, doesn’t his past dictate that he lacks credibility on such matters? There has to be a better way to report things like this. President Trump, who has repeatedly made demonstrable false claims about President Obama in the past, now has made new claims about Obama that good journalistic practice dictate be treated with profound and appropriate skepticism.
He need to be treated like the Boy Who Cried Wolf. If the media really despises Trump, the best way to drive him crazy is to simply ignore him.
